R: @jbonofre
Travis failure fixed by https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/pull/1226

Spoke with some other folks in person. I think we want to keep the default `mvn verify` profile to only the subsets of commands that a Beam **user** wants to run. To that end:
- we should leave RAT off
- we should remove checkstyle and other similar things
- we should document very concisely in the contribution guide what command Jenkins precommit runs (maybe it should be `-Pprecommit` ?) for contributors who want to test locally
+1, it makes sense to me.

CC: @dhalperi
R: -@dhalperi
R: @robertwb
Makes sense, closing this PR, some further commentary on the JIRA: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-860
@dhalperi so just to be clear, current implementation in master _is_ thread safe ?
@dhalperi , please let me know if you have additional comments?
This PR has gotten a bit old, and we have a good number of IT tests now running. Do we still need this? If so, I think a rebase & retest is in order.
@amitsela yes, the current implementation is threadsafe to the best of my knowledge.
It's fine as-is, but Jesse should merge when he thinks it's ready

@aviemzur can you check with microbenchmark (as Dan proposed) if the current synchronized implementation degrades performance ?
If so, it's best to change this PR to revolve around registration of the AvroCoder with JavaSerializatio  for Kryo.
Jenkins failure was a flake, and Travis passed 3/5, so this is g2g. But now that we've improved our Travis reliability, a rebase might get both green.
Hmm. Sorter tests did not run. Can you try to figure out why? https://builds.apache.org/job/beam_PreCommit_MavenVerify/4422/
R: @chamikaramj updated the documentation now.
And yet, they seem to have run from the console output. Not sure why the two disagree, but never mind for now.
LGTM

I don't have this paged in, and neither the bug nor this PR make clear to me why `AvroCoder` is using Java serialization at all. Given the to/from methods `@JsonCreator` and `asCloudObject`, it should be Jackson-JSON-serialized like all other non-`CustomCoder`s.

FWIW serialization proxies like the one in `AvroCoder` are a standard way to correctly use Java's serialization APIs when you actually design your serialization somewhat. It is pretty surprising that the Kryo/Spark community hasn't been bitten repeatedly, if it is just ignored.

Perhaps everyone just choose between (1) use Java serialization if you don't want to design your serialization (lots of pitfalls, but OK for transmission-only uses) or when you outgrow that (2) use something else entirely. Certainly that's been my trajectory in the past...

We need to take path (2) for Beam coders. We may support language-specific coders in some ways, but they will be by far more costly and non-portable. `AvroCoder` must not be one of them, so it needs to just have a JSON format.
R: @robertwb

Ok, I took a stab at this and was able to maintain the existing performance and thread safe like we had before and make the serialization cross compatible with Kryo and Java. Please either merge my commits (https://github.com/lukecwik/incubator-beam/tree/fix941) on top of your existing PR here or close this PR and I can open a new one for review based upon what I have.

@aviemzur What do you think?
Once my credentials are ready, I'll merge.
Ugh. Looks like #1226 did not completely fix the shade plugin bug ("String index out of range: 87"). Anyway it's unrelated to the current PR.
LGTM.

@swegner I have addressed your comments. Here's what I added and left for later:
- I **added** an `ItemMatcher` that helps simplify unit tests for display data. I have also added the `ItemMatcher` to our current tests.
- I **added** functions `DisplayDataItem.drop_if_none()`, and `DisplayDataItem.drop_if_default(def_val)` to be consistent with the model in the Java SDK.
- I **added** an extra text case for file pattern prefix/suffix treatment in `NativeFileSink`. We have only two cases at the moment.
- I did **not add** exhaustive test cases for file pattern prefix/suffix treatment in `NativeFileSink`. The code for that seems to not be part of the Python SDK.
- I did **not add** small "integration tests" to make sure display data gets added - I'd like to leave this for a later change (after I've thoroughly studied Java's [`ReadTest.testBoundedPrimitiveDisplayData()`](https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/blob/master/sdks/java/core/src/test/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/ReadTest.java#L110)).

Please review, and let me know what you think.
-P. : )
LGTM, merging

R: @aaltay
R: @robertwb
Example failure reminder: https://s3.amazonaws.com/archive.travis-ci.org/jobs/172122953/log.txt (in #1201)

How I ran mvn for debugging:
1. Ran mvn clean install once
2. `~/maven-3.3.9/bin/mvnDebug -pl :beam-runners-spark -Peclipse-jdt -e install org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-shade-plugin:2.4.3:shade`
I suspect this is a bug in the Eclipse compiler. I'll try to figure that out in parallel.

Yup, definitely Eclipse compiler bug. Set IntelliJ to use Eclipse compiler, asked to compile project.

`javap './runners/spark/target/classes/org/apache/beam/runners/spark/translation/SparkProcessContext$1.class'`

Please file a bug report, and include the following information:

Manually fixed the checkstyle issue and merged.

Wowza. That's "fun".

> Still need to verify the path of pure python on client side and c++ version on worker.

This is worth checking but probably won't matter because you never pickle anything in the protobuf implementation, just the class of the message.  The way a class object is pickled should just be by name.
